Award.AwardTitle: Studies of Mixed Polymer Brushes Designed for Periodic In-Plane Order
Award.AbstractNarration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymers are valuable materials in everyday life. These long-chain molecules are the basis of industries ranging from food packaging to medical device manufacture to the clothing we wear. Polymers are critical components in the nanotechnology revolution enabling the manufacture of microelectronics that make possible smart phones. This project studies mixed polymer brushes, that is, more than one kind of polymer chain tied to a surface. Unique features of polymer brushes compared to other polymer systems are that they are bound to a surface, extended perpendicular to the surface, and have a controlled thickness and controlled surface chemistry. We will study how mixtures of two brushes phase separate, like oil and water, and form structures smaller than possible with today's advanced patterning methods. Over length scales of a few nanometers the nature of a surface can be transformed from a rigid inorganic structure to one that is soft and organic. Computer models predict symmetrical, periodic structures that we will explore as new nanostructures, as new energy storage materials and as new materials for biotechnology applications. We will work with computer experts to improve their theory and models by providing information about how well their concepts correctly predict these new mixed brush coatings. The research program will engage students in polymer science and materials research, foster globally aware graduate students and train students to work in a collaborative environment. Graduate students will in turn serve as mentors and role models to undergraduate students from Cornell and other universities, while gaining supervisory skills. REU students from other schools with an emphasis on underrepresented students will participate in research during the summer months. The PI and graduate student volunteers will interact with high school teachers in an RET program and teachers' workshops.


PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This fundamental research program will investigate the synthesis, processing and characterization of mixed polymer brushes designed to form controlled periodic spacings in the plane of the brush film. By using mixed polymer brushes of coil-coil and rod-coil architectures and harnessing their in-plane phase separation we will create patterned structures with controlled topography, porosity or multipath transport properties. Mixed polymer brushes will be synthesized using living radical polymerization of flexible coil polymers and Kumada chemistry of conjugated rod polymers. The in-plane phase separation process of dense brushes with controlled brush uniformity will be investigated. Studies will make use of new binary brush initiators developed using Passerini chemistry to form coil-type homopolymer, diblock copolymer and multiblock copolymer mixed brushes. The phase behavior and how it compares to computational predictions will be studied for homopolymer and block copolymer pairs with the goal of creating stable periodic structures. Computational materials science through our collaborations will be used to guide brush design and selection, to predict physical structure and to aid examination of the physical properties of these new materials. To achieve our goal of uniform long-range order in these brush layers, we will investigate solvent vapor annealing and thermal transient laser spike annealing in conjunction with guiding structures. Characterization of the brushes will be made using a variety of analytical methods including X-ray reflectometry, grazing incidence (GI) SAXS and WAXS, neutron reflectivity and STORM superresolution fluorescence microscopy measurements. Charge transport measurements will be carried out on new rod-coil mixed brushes. Each technique will provide information about the internal or surface organization of the material and will aid our understanding of the structures produced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This program has focused on the study of polymer chains grown from surfaces to make surface attached polymer brushes. Polymers a long-chain molecules, built from many similar repeating units, that we are familiar with in the clothes we wear, the plastics we use in electronics and the packaging that keeps our food and medicines safe. In our studies we have looked at polymers that are either stiff or flexible and attached them to surfaces as brushes in mixtures of two kinds of polymer chains. Flexible brushes make soft surfaces that over the distance of just a few nanometers can change a hard surface into a soft surface. Stiff brushes are different and we have learned how to make them stand up from a surface in the form of teepees, resembling the spikes found on viruses. The processing we use swells the brush attached to a surface in a good solvent and then we expose the brushes to a bad solvent for the stiff polymer. As the good solvent is removed, the stiff polymers collect together and form the tepees. The combination of a hard spiky and a soft surface provide interesting opportunities to study cell-surface interactions to improve our understanding of how cells work, to study the piezoelectric behavior of certain stiff protein chains to create actuators on a surface, to explore the vertical conductivity of conjugated (conducting) polymers to aid in the creation of new electronics and to examine the effect of liquid crystals on a surface to form new sensors and displays. These results are the subject of studies in a new research program.

Broader Impacts: The research program also served as a mechanism to engage students in polymer and materials science, create globally aware graduate students and expose students to a collaborative environment. Graduate students worked with other research groups as parts of teams and took part in international exchange visits. Graduate students worked as mentors and role models to undergraduate students, while at the same time gaining supervisory skills and leadership abilities. Two PhD students completed their studies under this program and will now work in US industry. About a dozen undergraduate students took part in this program. Undergraduates from Cornell engaged in research during the academic year while summer students from other universities participated in research during the summer months. Lessons learned from these research programs were factored into programs in which the PI and graduate student volunteers interact with high school teachers to teach them better how to teach science.  In outreach activities Ober and his group have developed lectures on polymers and other materials as educational tools for high school teachers while working with outreach programs at Cornell. The PI, with graduate student and post-doctoral involvement, met with high school teachers in New York City, provided a keynote lecture to teachers on polymers in nanoscience and took part in a chemistry education workshop. An important as?pect of meeting with teachers is its multiplying effect. In addition, Ober was involved in hosting 60 undergraduate REU researchers from across the US at Cornell University at an undergraduate research conference during August 2019.
